verses.text: Brothers and sisters, I could not speak to you as spiritual people but as people of the flesh, as infants in Christ.
verses.comment: Paul is showing a distinction between maturity and immaturity in spiritual matters. The term 'infants in Christ' emphasizes the need for growth within a lived Christian community, and hints at the necessity for ongoing formation—a concept found throughout Christian tradition.

verses.text: I fed you with milk, not solid food, for you were not ready for it. And even now you are not yet ready,
verses.comment: Spiritual milk here refers to the basic teachings of the faith. Paul’s gradual approach to spiritual revelation mirrors the method used elsewhere in Scripture—for example, Jesus guiding the disciples (John 16:12). It suggests a developmental process in spiritual understanding.

verses.text: for you are still fleshly. For since there is jealousy and strife among you, are you not fleshly, and behaving as mere humans?
verses.comment: Paul contrasts 'fleshly' (worldly) conduct with spiritual living. The presence of jealousy and division points to the need for unity in the church, reflecting Christ’s prayer for oneness in John 17:21.

verses.text: For when one says, “I follow Paul,” and another, “I follow Apollos,” are you not acting like humans?
verses.comment: The division over church leaders reflects a misunderstanding of Christian identity. Paul emphasizes unity in Christ, a theme foundational for the one, visible and united Church.

verses.text: What then is Apollos? And what is Paul? Servants through whom you believed, as the Lord assigned to each.
verses.comment: Paul describes himself and Apollos as mere servants—ministers, not sources of the faith. This highlights the theology of apostolic ministry, showing the importance of service and stewardship in the life of the Church.

verses.text: I planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the growth.
verses.comment: Human effort alone does not bring spiritual fruit; God is the true source of growth. Paul’s agricultural metaphor underscores the harmony between God’s sovereignty and human cooperation—a mystery present in the sacramental life of the Church.

verses.text: So neither the one who plants nor the one who waters is anything, but only God who gives growth.
verses.comment: Paul stresses humility among church workers. God alone deserves credit for spiritual success. This underscores the biblical principle that ministry is participation in God’s action, not its source.

verses.text: The one who plants and the one who waters are one, and each will receive his own reward according to his labor.
verses.comment: Unity in purpose and diversity in roles among God’s servants point to a cooperative vision for ministry. The teaching on rewards also supports the doctrine that good works have significance by God’s grace.

verses.text: For we are God’s co-workers; you are God’s field, God’s building.
verses.comment: Paul’s use of ‘God’s field’ and ‘God’s building’ anticipates his later discussion of the Church as the temple. The concept of being co-workers with God is a profound mystery—humans participate in divine work by grace.

verses.text: According to the grace God gave me, like a skilled master builder, I laid a foundation, and another builds upon it. Let each one be careful how he builds upon it.
verses.comment: Paul’s image of all Christians building on one foundation teaches the importance of apostolic succession and correct doctrine, preserving unity and truth in the Church.

verses.text: For no one can lay any foundation other than the one already laid, which is Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Jesus, foreshadowed as the ‘cornerstone’ in the Old Testament, is the essential and singular foundation of the Church. This highlights His unique, divine authority (see Matt. 16:18), central to Christian life and worship.

verses.text: Now if anyone builds on the foundation with gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, or straw,
verses.comment: Paul’s list of building materials refers to the value and endurance of one’s works—eternal versus temporal. It subtly encourages the Christian life emphasizing virtue, fidelity, and right teaching.

verses.text: each one’s work will become evident, for the Day will disclose it, because it will be revealed with fire, and the fire will test what sort of work each has done.
verses.comment: This verse alludes to a future judgment where works are tested—a foundation for the doctrine of purification and the reality of final reward. The imagery echoes the refining fire described in prophetic texts.

verses.text: If the work that someone has built on the foundation remains, he will receive a reward.
verses.comment: Reward for enduring works suggest an economy of grace where faithful service is honored. The concept of reward for Christian labor appears consistently throughout the Scriptures.

verses.text: If anyone’s work is burned up, he will suffer loss, but he himself will be saved, though only as through fire.
verses.comment: Salvation ‘through fire’ hints at a purifying process even for believers whose works fall short. This has historically supported the teaching that believers may undergo post-mortem purification before final glory.

verses.text: Do you not know that you are God’s temple and that God’s Spirit dwells in you?
verses.comment: The indwelling of the Spirit transforms the church and believer into God’s temple, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy. This emphasizes the sacredness of the church community and the necessity of spiritual unity.

verses.text: If anyone destroys God’s temple, God will destroy him. For God’s temple is holy, and you are that temple.
verses.comment: Paul issues a grave warning against division and sacrilege, grounding the sanctity of the believing community in God’s holiness. The holy nature of the Church is a central theme in both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: Let no one deceive himself. If anyone among you thinks he is wise in this age, let him become a fool, that he may become wise.
verses.comment: True wisdom comes from divine revelation, not human opinion. Paul encourages humility before God, a core mark of the saints and the wise.

verses.text: For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God. For it is written, 'He catches the wise in their craftiness,'
verses.comment: Paul quotes Job to show that worldly wisdom is ultimately opposed to God’s ways. Spiritual discernment is imperative for the true worshiper.

verses.text: and again, 'The Lord knows the reasoning of the wise, that it is futile.'
verses.comment: Paul continues to stress the insufficiency of human wisdom, centering all true knowledge in God. Genuine Christian teaching is rooted in divine revelation.

verses.text: So then, let no one boast in men. For all things are yours,
verses.comment: Boasting in human leaders is discouraged as all Christians share in the inheritance of Christ. Paul affirms the universality and unity of believers’ spiritual heritage.

verses.text: whether Paul or Apollos or Cephas, or the world or life or death, or the present or the future—all are yours,
verses.comment: Name-dropping key church leaders (Paul, Apollos, Cephas/Peter) highlights the continuity and diversity within the apostolic ministry. All good things are shared in Christ by virtue of being part of His Church.

verses.text: and you are Christ’s, and Christ is God’s.
verses.comment: Final emphasis that Christians belong to Christ, who Himself is in perfect unity with the Father. This passage reveals both Christ’s divinity and His filial relationship to God, a key point in Christian doctrine about the Trinity and the church’s unity.
